message_1: A ferris wheel has a diameter of 50ft and makes one revolution every 30 seconds. If a passenger is at the 10 o'clock position when the ride starts, write an equation for the height of the passenger (in feet) as a function of time (in seconds). At what time(s) will the passenger be at the highest point on the ferris wheel, and what will be their height at that point?
message_2:
Let h(t) be the height of the passenger as a function of time t (in seconds). The radius of the ferris wheel is 25 ft (half of the diameter). The height of the passenger can be modeled using a sinusoidal function, specifically a cosine function since the passenger starts at the 10 o'clock position.

The general form of the cosine function is h(t) = A * cos(B * (t - C)) + D, where A is the amplitude, B is the frequency, C is the phase shift, and D is the vertical shift.

In this case, the amplitude A is equal to the radius of the ferris wheel, which is 25 ft. The frequency B can be found by dividing 2π by the period of the ferris wheel (30 seconds), so B = 2π/30. There is no phase shift C, as the passenger starts at the 10 o'clock position. The vertical shift D is equal to the radius of the ferris wheel, which is 25 ft.

So the equation for the height of the passenger as a function of time is:

h(t) = 25 * cos((2π/30) * t) + 25

To find the time(s) when the passenger is at the highest point on the ferris wheel, we need to find when the cosine function reaches its maximum value, which is 1. This occurs when the argument of the cosine function is an even multiple of π:

(2π/30) * t = 2nπ, where n is an integer.

Solving for t, we get:

t = 30n

Since the ferris wheel makes one revolution every 30 seconds, the passenger will be at the highest point every 30 seconds (t = 0, 30, 60, 90, ...).

At the highest point, the height of the passenger is the maximum value of the function h(t):

h(t) = 25 * cos((2π/30) * t) + 25 = 25 * 1 + 25 = 50 ft

So the passenger will be at the highest point on the ferris wheel every 30 seconds, and their height at that point will be 50 ft.
